descript.abstract: Manufacturing Centers, 1996 is a point theme representing major manufacturing centers worldwide. Attribute information includes the name of the center, the industrial structure, the size, the relative ecological hazard and the manufacturing industry code.
descript.purpose: For educational, non-commercial purposes. This dataset is appropriate for use in a GIS.
descript.supplinf: The manufacturing industry is one of the leading sectors of the worlds economy. It is made up of a group of industries that manufacture or process raw materials produced by mining, agriculture, forestry, fishery, and hunting, as well as manufacture semi finished products. The most significant branches of the manufacturing industry are machine building, metalworking, ferrous metallurgy, nonferrous metallurgy, oil processing, chemicals, woodworking, pulp and paper, textiles, clothing, boot and shoe making, food industries, and production of building materials. The manufacturing industry is typically a leading factor in the development of countries, their regions, and large cities, although its role varies in space and time. Distinctions in industrial development among regions are decreasing. Industry plays a relatively greater role in regions that most recently began the process of industrial development. Rapid industrialization of previously backward regions does little to change their relative levels of economic development. The new industry does not produce enough income per capita, which is the principal value of economic development.

Outside the United States Please direct all inquiries regarding software/data pricing, sales, support, and consulting services to your local ESRI International Distributor. This information can be found at http://gis.esri.com/intldist/contactint.cfm. For other questions or comments, you may contact ESRI headquarters by e-mail, telephone, or fax or write to us.

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 3; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.1850

procstep.procdesc:
The manufacturing industry maps were compiled from cartographic and statistical materials as well as specialized journals on various manufacturing industries. They show the most significant centers of manufacturing for each continent as well as their impacts on the environment. In general the cities with populations greater than 100,000 are shown. In India and China, some cities of this size with poorly developed industry are omitted. At the same time, many small centers (with populations even less than 25,000) are included to characterize more accurately, from a geographical point of view, the areas of disperse industry. The impact of the industry on the regional environment corresponds to the number of regional industrial centers. In some cases, small centers with particularly hazardous production and impacts on the environment are shown.
Manufacturing Industry -- References:
Africa in figures. 1988. New York. 125 pp.
Annuaire statistique de la Belgique, 1989. Bruxelles. XIV, 791 pp.
Annuaire statistique de la France, 1988. Paris. XVI, 864 pp.
Annuaire statistique de la Suisse, 1982. Geneva. 654 pp.
Annuario statistia italiano, 1988. Roma. 719 pp.
Annual abstract of statistics, 1989. London. 336 pp.
Census of Manufactures, 1977. Washington, D.C. 13 files.
Latin America and Caribbean, 1986. London. 216 pp.
Latin America atudies, 1988. Cop.
Statistical Abstract of the United States, 1989. Washington, D.C. 956 pp.
Statistical Handbook of Japan, 1989. Tokyo. 158 pp.
Statistical Yearbook, 1990/1991. New York. XIV, 1, 109 pp.
Statistical Yearbook for Asia and the Far East, 1989. Bangkok. 458 pp.
Statistical Yearbook of the Netherlands, 1988. The Hague. 427 pp.
Statistical Yearbook of the Republic of China, 1981. Hong Kong. 743 pp.
Statistisches Handbuch fur die Republic Osterreich, 1989. Wien. 562 pp.
Statistisches Jahrbuch deutsher shadbe, 1989. Leipzig. 432 pp.
Statistisches Jahrbuch fur die Bundesrepublic Deutschland, 1989. Wiesbaden. 716 pp.
Statistisk arsbok for Norge, 1989. Oslo. 496 pp.
Statistisk arsbok for Sverige, 1989. Stockholm. 562 pp.
Upravleniye narodnym khozyaystvom v sotsialisticheskikh stranakh, 1989. (Economy management in socialist countries, 1989.) 1991. The USSR Academy of Sciences, INION, Moscow. Parts 1 and 2. 203 pp.
Yearbook. Australia, 1983. Canberra. 800 pp.
Yearbook of Labor statistics, 1989-90. Geneva. 1,094 pp.
Datasets for each continent were converted from ESRI coverage to the ESRI shapefile format using the 'copy features' tool and merged into one layer using the 'merge' tool.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Code for any diacritical marks in the manufacturing center name
Indicates a manufacturing center's type of industrial structure

edom.edomvd: Production of detergent and related materials
General machine building, metal working, and metal repairing
Industrial equipment and other types of manufacture
Manufacture of electrical household and lighting appliances
Woodworking, pulp and paper, and wood and chemical industry
Hemp and jute, and sesame production
Production of nonwoven and other materials
Tanning, boot and shoe, and fur industry
Production of building materials, porcelain and faience

attr.attrdef: Relative size of a manufacturing center based on output
The relative ecological hazard based on the type and amount of industry in the manufacturing center
